commitResults.messageTitle: Rename main class, add greatings
Add support for echo, personalized my chatbox
Add the ability to store whatever text entered by the user and display them back to the user when requested.
Add the ability to mark tasks as done. Optionally, add the ability to change the status back to not done.
Add support for tracking three types of tasks: Todos, Deadlines, and Events. Add a class TaskList and three classes Todo, Deadline, and Event all extending class Task

Teach the chatbot to deal with errors such as incorrect inputs entered by the user. I handle these 3 exceptions: 1."UnknownCommandException": when the user enters a command that can not be identified 2."EmptyDescriptionException": when the user only enters a task but without descriptions 3."InvalidFormatException": when the user enters both task and its descriptions but the descriptions are not following the format requirement
Add support for deleting tasks from the list.
Add comments for classes and functions
Test using the I/O redirection technique Update input.txt and EXPECTE.TXT accordingly
Add Storage class for task persistence
commitResults.messageBody:
The current taskList cannot be saved to hard drive.

A class Storage is being created to help saving and loading taskList to and from disk drive. Relative classes including Task and its subclasses, and James are all updated.

commitResults.messageTitle: Merge branch 'branch-Level-7'
Update Deadline class to recognize date
commitResults.messageBody:
Previously Tasks can not recognize the date user inputs.

The class Deadline is updated so that it takes in a specific format of user's input for the date, and stores it in a LocalDate datatype.

commitResults.messageTitle: Merge branch 'branch-Level-8'
Add Ui class
commitResults.messageBody:
Previously all I/Os are handled by the main function in class James.

This violates the OOP principle. So a new class Ui is created to handle all I/O works.

commitResults.messageTitle: Introduce Command, Storage, and Ui classes for OOP refactor
commitResults.messageBody:
The application currently handles user interaction, file operations, and execution logic within a few overloaded classes.

This tight coupling makes the code difficult to test and violates the Single Responsibility Principle, as the logic for printing, saving, and executing commands is intermingled.

Implement a Command hierarchy to handle execution logic, a Storage class to manage hard disk I/O, and a Ui class to encapsulate all user interactions.

commitResults.messageTitle: Replace inline number parsing with InvalidNumberException
commitResults.messageBody:
The application handles number-related errors through standard Java exceptions directly within the James class.

Standard exceptions do not provide the specific, user-friendly feedback required for the chatbot, and handling them in the main loop leads to messy execution logic.

Remove the generic number exception handling in James.java and implement a dedicated InvalidNumberException class to manage task range and format errors.

commitResults.messageTitle: refactor and organize classes into james package
commitResults.messageBody:
The project currently uses the default package with all source files
located in the root directory.

This structure lacks organization, violates standard Java coding
conventions, and makes the codebase harder to maintain as it grows.

Move all Java classes into the james package. Update the directory
structure to match the package hierarchy and adjust all class
declarations and internal imports.

Use checkStyle to detect coding style violations for command classes
Use checkStyle to detect coding style violations for exception classes
Use checkStyle to detect coding style violations for mainWindow class
Use checkStyle to detect coding style violations for task classes
Use checkStyle to detect coding style violations for Storage class
Use checkStyle to detect coding style violations for TaskList class
Add assertions to James main class
commitResults.messageBody:
The James class currently initializes components and processes user input without verifying internal state assumptions.

This poses a risk of unhandled null pointer exceptions or undefined behavior if dependencies like Storage or Ui are not correctly instantiated before use.

Add Java assertions to the constructor and getResponse method to validate that the file path is valid and that all component objects are non-null.

This is done to enforce class invariants and fail fast during development using Java's native assertion mechanism, which documents the code's expected state.

 These checks verify the critical lifecycle state of the application before processing commands.

commitResults.messageTitle: Add assertions to Parser input and logic
commitResults.messageBody:
The Parser class currently assumes that inputs like command strings and task lists are always valid and non-null.

This increases the risk of NullPointerExceptions propagating deep into the parsing logic where they are harder to debug.

Add assertions to the beginning of parseCommand and parseLine to verify inputs are not null, and add an internal assertion in the event parsing logic to verify split assumptions.

This is done to enforce strict preconditions for the parser utility and to document the specific structural assumptions made when splitting complex command strings.

commitResults.messageTitle: Add assertions to Storage class
commitResults.messageBody:
The Storage class currently operates on file paths and task lists without verifying they are non-null.

This risks creating invalid files or throwing NullPointerExceptions during critical save/load operations.

Add assertions to the constructor to validate the file path and to saveTasks to ensure the task list is present.

This is done to prevent file corruption or data loss by ensuring that I/O operations only proceed with valid data.
